Expectation1: Look out for each other's safety and well-being
Situation1: One sibling is preparing to try a new skateboard trick on a steep, uneven ramp.
Situation2: They have argued repeatedly this week about finances.
Story: I stood at the edge of the skate park, heart pounding as I watched my stepbrother strap on his helmet. He grinned at me, ready to try the new trick he’d been talking about all week. The ramp looked even steeper up close, the concrete chipped and uneven. As his step-sibling, I knew I should look out for him, maybe talk him out of it, or at least make sure he was being safe. But my phone buzzed again—my girlfriend’s name lighting up the screen. Another message, probably about the argument we’d had last night. We’d been fighting all week about money, and she wanted me to call her, to finally talk things through and resolve it. I felt pulled in two directions: if I left to call her, I’d be abandoning my stepbrother when he might need me most. If I stayed, I’d be letting my girlfriend down again, risking our relationship. My stomach twisted as I tried to figure out who needed me more right now, feeling the weight of both roles pressing in on me.
